summary: Edward G. Tichborn was associated with the CIA, as evidenced by documents detailing his contract, compensation, and activities. He was involved in operational deployments and used proprietary companies. A memorandum summarizes his debriefing after a trip to Cuba, where he provided observations and suggestions regarding Fidel Castro, potential contacts of influence, and a possible State Department agent. His financial arrangements with the CIA are also documented, including bank account details for operational advances and salary payments. The documents span from 1960 to 1968, indicating a sustained relationship with the CIA during this period.
significance: The documents suggest Edward G. Tichborn was a CIA operative involved in activities related to Cuba and potentially other operational deployments. His debriefing after a trip to Cuba and his financial arrangements with the CIA are documented. While the documents do not explicitly link him to the JFK assassination, his involvement with the CIA and Cuba during this period could be of interest in the broader context of the assassination.
